thread.title: Sydney girls hit by a falling tree branch
thread.title_full: Sydney girls hit by a falling tree branch | Daily Mail Online

author: Chris Pleasance For Daily Mail Australia
title: Sydney girls hit by a falling tree branch
text:
Four teenage schoolgirls have been rushed to hospital with head and back injuries after being hit by a falling tree branch.
The Year 12 pupils from Heathcote High School were sitting underneath a tree at around 1.30pm when a large branch snapped off and fell on them.
One girl suffered head injuries, another two suffered back injuries, and a fourth was taken to hospital with unknown injuries, an ambulance spokesman told Daily Mail Australia.
Four schoolgirls have been taken to hospital with head and neck injuries after a tree branch fell on them outside Heathcote High School at around 1.45pm
One girl suffered head injuries, another two suffered back injuries, and a fourth was taken to hospital with unknown injuries
Three other girls were treated by paramedics at the scene but did not need to be taken to hospital.
All of the patients are believed to be around 17 years old, the spokesman said.
All four girls have been taken to St George Hospital.
Video from the scene shows one student being covered by a tarpaulin while firefighters use a chainsaw to cut them free.
Another girl can be see laying on a stretcher while wearing a neck brace as she it put into the back of an ambulance.
Video shows emergency workers holding a tarpaulin above one victim as firefighters worked to free her from under the heavy branch
The Department for Education says it is investigating the incident, adding that it is school policy to have the trees regularly inspected by an arborist
In a statement posted on their Facebook page, Heathcote High School officials said: 'There was an incident today where a tree branch fell on four Year 12 students.
'They were given medical attention by ambulance officers and transported to hospital. We are awaiting a report on their medical condition. The students' families have been notified.'
The incident is believed to have taken place at lunch time, as Year 7, 11 and 12 students returned for the first day since school holidays.
A New South Wales Department of Education spokesman said school guidelines recommend having trees regularly inspected by an arborist.
The spokesman confirmed an investigation into the incident has been launched, though added that the branch fell 'without warning'.
